title: English (1911) Tercentenary KJV Bible (Vol 1-3)
description:
The 1911 Tercentenary KJV Bible, published by the New York Bible and Common Prayer Book Society, commemorates the 300th anniversary of the King James Bible. Reverend Henry Barker, a less-known but significant figure in the Church, authored the preface and provided an insightful historical account of the Bible's manuscript origins. Barker delves into the formation of the biblical canon and the pioneering efforts of reformers like John Wyclif in the 14th century and William Tyndale in the 16th century to translate the Bible into vernacular languages, thus democratizing its content for the general populace.

Barker's narrative not only traces the progression of the English Bible but also skillfully contextualizes it within the broader landscape of social and political upheaval that spurred the early translations. His comprehensive account sheds light on the multifaceted journey of the Bible in English, from its early manuscript forms to the celebrated King James Version. This volume serves as a testament to the enduring impact of the King James Bible, both as a religious text and a cornerstone of linguistic and cultural development. It offers readers a detailed exploration of the historical and theological significance of one of the most influential books in the English-speaking world, making it an invaluable resource for scholars, theologians, and anyone interested in the history of the Bible.
